intro: Malvastrum garckeanum var. paranense, commonly known as the Brazilian mallow, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant features showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are heart-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and somewhat woody. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open habitats like grasslands and disturbed areas.
